title: FTE World Innovation Summit sponsor, tours and pitches preview - Future Travel Experience
description:
See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >> Gensler: delivering a more intuitive, cohesive and carefully crafted passenger journey through design For more than 50 years, Gensler – a Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – has been a leading global architecture, interiors, planning, and strategic consulting firm that partners with public and private sector clients to achieve measurable results through design.
See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >> solutions4networks: network infrastructure provider for PIT’s Terminal Modernization Program For over 25 years, solutions4networks – a Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – has helped businesses meet the challenges of their industries and quantify the return and value of infrastructure investments.
“We’ll have multiple members of the Zensors team in attendance at the FTE World Innovation Summit and welcome the opportunity to connect.” Hear more from Zensors at the FTE World Innovation Summit.
See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >> Exclusive tour of the new PIT baggage system for FTE Baggage Innovation Working Group members, plus Journey Robotics demo for all FTE World Innovation Summit attendees Members of the FTE Baggage Innovation Working Group will convene for a series of activities alongside the FTE World Innovation Summit.
See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >> You may also be interested in
text:
The FTE World Innovation Summit – the air transport industry’s most anticipated innovation event of the year – takes place on 13-15 May 2025, hosted by Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT). It is the ultimate platform to discover fresh ideas and bold new approaches that will drive real change across the sector. Read our in-depth interviews with a broad range of pioneering event sponsors, plus learn more about the guided tours and exclusive first-look at the landmark new PIT terminal, innovation tours of cutting-edge companies across Pittsburgh, ‘Meet the Innovators’ pitch sessions, and more.

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

LG Business Solutions: customised solutions tailored to the unique needs of airports

LG Electronics provides digital signage and information display solutions for transportation. These solutions help improve the experience for passengers and transportation service providers. “LG is one of the few in the display industry to offer LCD, DVLED, OLED, and Transparent Technology all with integrated SOC and WebOS operating System,” explains Dan Verbsky, Key Account Manager – Transportation, LG Business Solutions.

LG Business Solutions continues to push the boundaries of technology with the introduction of the new cable-less design solution for the LG DVLED MAGNIT product. “The cable-less signal transmission technology in the LG MAGNIT is a game-changer for simplifying large screen installations,” Verbsky shares. “By eliminating the need for signal and power cables between the cabinets, it not only streamlines the setup process but also makes the rear structure much cleaner and more organised. The fact that only six signal and six power cables are needed for a UHD resolution screen with a 16:9 ratio is impressive, especially for large-scale displays. This block assembly design seems perfect for venues where a sleek, professional look is important, and it could significantly reduce installation time and maintenance hassles.”

As a Gold Sponsor, LG Business Solutions will be highlighting its diverse line-up – from DVLED Ticket Counter Ribbons to 4K LCD EVIDS – at the FTE World Innovation Summit. “It is a fantastic opportunity to highlight LG’s cutting-edge technology in a prominent setting like Pittsburgh International Airport,” says Verbsky. “The FTE events provide a great opportunity for networking and collaboration! Engaging with attendees, understanding their airport-related challenges, and brainstorming solutions for improving passenger experiences are incredibly valuable. Every LG employee attending the FTE World Innovation Summit is a display industry expert who enjoys engaging in conversation. We encourage you to visit our tables and connect with us!”

Hear more from LG Business Solutions at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Scott Oranen, Senior Account Manager Transportation, LG Business Solutions USA, is participating in a PIT Transformation Deep Dive session focused on Technology & Innovation.

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

TSI Touch: high-performance interactive solutions optimised for the demands of air transport

TSI Touch is a leading provider of commercial touchscreen and protective solutions, enhancing passenger experience and operational efficiency in the air transport industry. Its touchscreen displays and durable protective technologies support applications such as passenger check-in, digital signage, and security screening.

“TSI Touch delivers high-performance interactive solutions optimised for the demands of air transport, including ruggedized protective glass for high-traffic areas, privacy-enhancing display technology, and custom touchscreens designed for seamless passenger interactions,” explains Jeana Schneck, Eastern US and International Sales Representative, TSI Touch. “Our solutions improve usability, durability, and security in aviation environments.”

TSI Touch recently introduced its patented Defender protective solution for DVLED video wall displays, as well as privacy-enhancing glass coverings that are being adopted for use in high-traffic environments where durability and security are critical.

As a Gold Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit, TSI Touch aims to showcase how its innovative touchscreen and protective solutions enhance efficiency, engagement, and security in air travel environments. “We look forward to connecting with industry leaders to explore new opportunities for interactive and durable digital signage solutions in airports and other transportation hubs,” says Schneck. “We value FTE’s focus on driving innovation in air travel and bringing together key decision-makers. This year, we’re excited to engage with industry leaders, demonstrate our latest solutions, and discuss how interactive and protective display technologies can enhance the passenger journey. Visit our table at the FTE World Innovation Summit – our team will be available for discussions on how TSI Touch can support your airport and airline technology initiatives.”

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

LAZ Parking: a unique suite of parking technology solutions that enhance CX and support onsite operations

LAZ Parking – a Gold Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – has developed into one of the largest privately held parking and transportation companies in North America. “Even though LAZ has been in business for over four decades, we did not enter the aviation sector until 12 years ago, when we secured our first airport contract at Oakland International Airport in 2013,” says Rick Ingram, Executive Vice President, LAZ Parking. “We have since become a leader in airport operations, with over 37 airport clients and 40 distinct operations in the United States and Canada.”

Some of LAZ’s most complex airport operations include:

Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT) – Parking and Shuttle Services

Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) – LAX-it TNC / Taxi & Shuttle, Curbside and Bus Transportation

Denver International Airport (DEN) – Parking Management, Shuttle Management

Nashville International Airport (BNA) – Parking Management, Valet Management

Edmonton International Airport (YEG) – Parking Management, Valet Services, and Shuttle Services

Cross Border Xpress Airport Terminal, Tijuana International Airport (TIJ) – San Diego, CA – All Landside Operations

“LAZ has developed a unique suite of parking technology solutions that enhance the customer experience while also supporting our onsite operations teams,” Ingram explains. “We offer online parking reservations through our LAZgo ecommerce platform, which is both convenient for customers and allows our operations teams to anticipate and plan for customer demand. Through the use of dynamic pricing, we have the ability to shift parking usage between different parking sites and revenue products, while capturing customer data that can be leveraged by our airport clients for broader marketing campaigns, targeted advertising, and email engagement campaigns. Through a unique relationship with Yext, a digital presence platform, LAZ connects LAZgo reservations directly to Google listings. Customers searching for an airport online will be shown a prominent ‘Book Online’ button directly on Google Maps.”

These technological innovations are customised for airports and offer significant enhancements to the customer experience, the parking operations, and how airports manage their business.

“LAZ is very proud to be a sponsor for the FTE World Innovation Summit,” Ingram adds. “We are looking forward to networking with airport and aviation experts from around the world and how each of them creates unique and travel experience.”

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

Mappedin: transforming complex indoor spaces into intuitive digital experiences

Mappedin is a leading provider of indoor mapping and wayfinding solutions that has expanded into the air transport industry. It specialises in transforming complex indoor spaces into intuitive digital experiences. “In airports, our technology enhances passenger experience by simplifying navigation through terminals, optimises operational efficiency for staff, supports digital transformation initiatives, and improves accessibility for all travellers,” explains Yuval Kossovsky, Managing Director of Transportation, Mappedin. “Our platform seamlessly integrates with existing airport systems to create connected digital experiences throughout the passenger journey – from parking to boarding gates – reducing traveller stress, minimising missed connections, and creating opportunities for increased non-aeronautical revenue through improved retail discovery.”

The company has launched many airport mapping solutions in the past 15 months, including airports such as OMA, SFB, BNE, OKC, YOW, LAX, YYC, AMS, MEL. Meanwhile, upcoming projects include Pittsburgh International Airport – host of the FTE World Innovation Summit – as well as Miami International Airport and Montréal-Trudeau International Airport.

As a Silver Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit, Mappedin aims to showcase its indoor mapping technology specifically tailored for airports, establish meaningful connections with airport operators and technology decision-makers, and gain deeper insights into the evolving needs of the air transport industry. “We seek to bring awareness to the MappedIn value proposition: how we deliver a great experience across mobile, directory, chat, and voice – with static and real-time data, all synced for a cost-effective solution,” Kossovsky shares. “Our ability to grow a solution based on airport size allows any airport to explore a potential solution that complements their existing technology.”

Furthermore, Kossovsky adds that MappedIn wants to learn about the unique challenges facing airports. “We want to understand airports’ digital transformation initiatives and understand their challenges first-hand, helping us refine our roadmap to better serve the airports evolving needs.”

Hear more from MappedIn at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Yuval Kossovsky, Managing Director, Transportation, Mappedin, is participating in a conference session focused on ‘Smart Airport Operations & Passenger Journeys’.

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

KBR: providing advanced process technologies and clean fuels solutions

For decades, KBR has been providing advanced process technologies. Its refining and clean fuels solutions empower refiners to efficiently produce and supply fuel products for automotive, manufacturing and aviation industries, to name a few. More recently, KBR has introduced PureSAF℠ technology that produces 100% fungible synthetic aviation fuel by utilising alternate feeds from renewable sources.

KBR and Avina are partnering on the development of innovative, advanced Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) technology. KBR will provide PureSAFSM technology for Avina’s state-of-the-art SAF production facility developments, one in Illinois and another in Pennsylvania. Both the plants will utilise renewable feedstocks to produce drop-in replacement of conventional jet fuel.

KBR’s PureSAFSM technology has been selected by Avina’s planned state-of-the-art SAF production facility development at Pittsburgh International Airport. This project, first to be developed at an airport, will support the existing and growing demands of aviation and manufacturing ecosystem players that have an affiliation with Pittsburgh International Airport.

As a global technology, engineering and solutions provider to governments and companies, KBR delivers innovative technology solutions for clean ammonia, hydrogen, refining, petrochemicals, plastics recycling, lithium and clean fuels and enables clients across industries to succeed in the evolving energy landscape within its Sustainable Technology Solutions business unit.

A Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit, this event marks KBR’s foray into FTE. As a technology provider, KBR aims to provide its innovative solutions to the aviation ecosystem.

“KBR is looking forward to gaining insights on the key challenges and opportunities from participants at the FTE World Innovation Summit,” says Hari Ravindran, SVP & Global Head, KBR Technology Solutions. “In particular, KBR would like to engage with participants and understand how our process technology innovations via solutions like PureSAFSM can support the demands of the industry.”

Hear more from KBR at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Monica Normark, Global Director Biofuels Technology, KBR, is participating in a session focused on ‘What are the best approaches to scaling the use of SAF, Electric & Hydrogen across air transport?’

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

Avina: a tech-enabled approach to bringing competitively priced synthetic aviation fuel to the market

Avina – a Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – is a clean fuels developer, focused on bringing competitively priced synthetic aviation fuel to the market at scale using a technology-enabled approach to help decarbonize the aviation industry.

Avina and KBR are partnering on the development of innovative, advanced Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) technology. “KBR will provide PureSAFSM technology as part of Avina’s state-of-the-art SAF production facility developments, one in Illinois and another in Pennsylvania,” explains Vishal Shah, Founder & CEO, Avina. “Both plants will utilise ethanol as feedstock to produce drop-in replacement of conventional jet fuel.”

Indeed, KBR will provide PureSAFSM technology as part of Avina’s planned state-of-the-art SAF production facility development at Pittsburgh International Airport. “Planning and development of the facility that will bring hundreds of jobs to the region will also provide an opportunity to connect the agriculture and aviation industry,” says Shah. “This project, first to be developed at an airport, will support the existing and growing demands of aviation and manufacturing ecosystem players that have an affiliation with Pittsburgh International Airport.”

Avina is excited to meet with key players in the aviation space, and exchange learnings and best practices with leading airlines, airports, suppliers, and other air transport innovators. “Bringing SAF to market is no easy feat; we recognise that it requires collaboration between developers, technology providers, airlines, airports, suppliers, policy makers, corporate partners, and others,” Shah adds. “The FTE World Innovation Summit provides the perfect platform to bring all of these stakeholders to the table and facilitate the conversations that will be necessary to bringing SAF to market cost-effectively and at scale.”

Hear more from Avina at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Vishal Shah, CEO, Avina, is participating in a session focused on ‘What are the best approaches to scaling the use of SAF, Electric & Hydrogen across air transport?’

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

Daifuku Airport America: a full-service provider of airport solutions that improve CX

Daifuku Airport America (Daifuku) – a Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – is a full-service provider of airport solutions that improve the passenger experience. Some of its solution categories are baggage handling systems (BHS), checkpoint screening systems, self bag drops and check-in kiosks, as well as flight information displays (FIDS).

“Our key objective at the FTE World Innovation Summit is to educate the industry on our product offerings and to help airports future-proof for passenger growth while solving the issues they face today,” shares Garrett Kelly, Executive Manager of Sales, Marketing and Estimating, Daifuku Airport America.

Daifuku’s AGV solution, called the Mobile Inspection Table (MIT), is currently running at many airports, including the new Pittsburgh International Airport terminal. “We have over 400 AGV’s operating in CBRA rooms throughout the US. Daifuku is also looking at new technology applications for our AGV solutions,” says Kelly. “For our baggage handling systems, Daifuku’s most recent innovations include Bag-UX, the first baggage hygiene solution of its kind, that improves bag orientation and reduces jams in the BHS. Our innovative solutions can also be seen in our early baggage storage systems, including our baggage tray system/individual carrier system.”

Daifuku has several products in development. It continues to look for ways to improve its solutions, such as the latest releases of its flight information display (FIDS), rapidhub airport operational database technology, and the SYM3 software which provides a 3D rendering of the BHS in real time.

Hear more from Daifuku Airport America at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Phil Wellington, Senior Project Manager, Daifuku Airport America, is participating in a Future Airports conference session focused on baggage.

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

Gensler: delivering a more intuitive, cohesive and carefully crafted passenger journey through design

For more than 50 years, Gensler – a Bronze Sponsor of the FTE World Innovation Summit – has been a leading global architecture, interiors, planning, and strategic consulting firm that partners with public and private sector clients to achieve measurable results through design.

Gensler + HDR, in association with luis vidal + architects, is the design and engineering team behind the Terminal Modernization Program at Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT). “Along with our multidisciplinary team of over two dozen engineering and design partners and the incredible team at the airport, we are delivering a more intuitive, cohesive and carefully crafted passenger journey,” says Carolyn Sponza, Principal and Studio Director, Gensler. “The new terminal will triple the amount of covered parking at PIT, significantly streamline the ticketing and security processes for a more efficient traveller journey, provide a modernised baggage handling system, debut four green terraces (two pre- and two post-security), and so much more.”

The aviation design team at Gensler is actively working on several terminal renovation and development projects across the U.S. which it is excited to debut to travellers over the next several years.

As someone who focuses on the planning and design part of aviation, Sponza always enjoys talking to those working in operations and product development. “It helps me understand what’s coming next for our industry and how we can future-proof our buildings to adapt to changes over the next 30-50 years,” Sponza shares. “At the FTE World Innovation Summit, we are excited to share a sneak peek of the revitalised Pittsburgh International Airport with airport innovators from around the world. The terminal will not only have an immense impact on Pittsburgh travellers but will also set a new standard for what the U.S. aviation experience can and should be.”

Hear more from Gensler at the FTE World Innovation Summit. Carolyn Sponza, Principal and Studio Director, Gensler, is participating in a PIT Transformation Deep Dive session focused on Design, Construction, Delivery & ORAT.

See the FTE World Innovation Summit agenda >> Register for the FTE World Innovation Summit >>

HDR: planning, designing, and modernising airport infrastructure

HDR delivers comprehensive aviation engineering services, focusing on planning, designing, and modernising airport infrastructure. It supports projects that enhance runway systems, terminal capacity, landside access and airside operations to improve safety and efficiency. With expertise in sustainability and innovative technologies, HDR helps airports meet growing demands while aligning with regulatory and environmental standards.

“HDR is integrating smart infrastructure and advanced data systems that enhance passenger experience and operational efficiency,” says Bill Peduzzi, PE, Aviation Director, HDR. “We prioritise adaptable terminal designs that accommodate emerging technologies such as biometric screening, automated baggage handling, and touchless check-in systems. Additionally, HDR emphasises sustainable design and energy-efficient solutions, helping airports create future-ready facilities while aligning with global environmental goals.

Gensler + HDR, in association with luis vidal + architects, is the design and engineering team behind the Terminal Modernization Program at Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT). title: Renewable Fuels Month Underway in Nebraska - The Bull - Rural Radio Network
description:
May marks Renewable Fuels Month in Nebraska, just in time for the start of the summer driving season.
Governor Jim Pillen will join in on the festivities by officially declaring May as Renewable Fuels Month on May 6.
As the nation’s second-largest ethanol producer, Nebraska is also looking to the future.
New legislation passed in 2024 offers a tax credit for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) made in Nebraska, fuel that can cut airline emissions by over 50% compared to conventional jet fuel.
Fueled by Nebraska, a coalition of biofuels groups including the Nebraska Corn Board, Nebraska Ethanol Board, Renewable Fuels Nebraska, and the Nebraska Soybean Board, invites communities, schools, and businesses to celebrate biofuels all month long.
text:
May marks Renewable Fuels Month in Nebraska, just in time for the start of the summer driving season. State leaders and ag organizations are encouraging Nebraskans to fill up with clean, cost-saving biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel that benefit both the economy and the environment.

Ethanol, Nebraska’s third-largest ag commodity, saved state drivers an estimated $375 million in 2024 when using blends of E10 and higher. Compared to regular gasoline, ethanol reduces emissions by up to 43%—making it a cleaner, more affordable option at the pump.

Governor Jim Pillen will join in on the festivities by officially declaring May as Renewable Fuels Month on May 6.

“Nebraskans are beginning to drive and take advantage of biofuel benefits more this month as the weather warms up for sports, vacations and holiday events,” said Brandon Hunnicutt, chairman of the Nebraska Corn Board. “By choosing a renewable fuel such as ethanol, drivers can support local agriculture, reduce their carbon footprint and save money on fuel costs.”

Most vehicles 2001 or newer can safely run on E15, while flex fuel vehicles can use up to E85 for even more savings. As the nation’s second-largest ethanol producer, Nebraska is also looking to the future. New legislation passed in 2024 offers a tax credit for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) made in Nebraska, fuel that can cut airline emissions by over 50% compared to conventional jet fuel.

Fueled by Nebraska, a coalition of biofuels groups including the Nebraska Corn Board, Nebraska Ethanol Board, Renewable Fuels Nebraska, and the Nebraska Soybean Board, invites communities, schools, and businesses to celebrate biofuels all month long.

title: Rotorcraft SAF Study Confirms Engines Burn Cleaner, Greener - Advanced BioFuels USA
description:
Rotorcraft SAF Study Confirms Engines Burn Cleaner, Greener by Tony Osborne (Aviation Week/The Weekly of Business Aviation) A study in Germany on the use of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) in helicopters, has confirmed considerable reductions in soot particles, confirming cleaner and greener operation of rotorcraft.
The trials performed by Germany’s DLR Aerospace Center and air rescue service ADAC using Airbus H145 and H135 twin-engine light helicopters found that the engines running on the SAF blend emitted significantly fewer ultrafine particles (UFP), and that both the Safran Arriel and Pratt and Whitney Canada engines were able to run “smoothly and reliably with the SAF blend.” The helicopters completed a combined 1,800 flight hr.
using a blend of SAF and conventional aviation fuel.
According to the DLR, the fuel contained up to 38% SAF that was produced from recycled vegetable or animal fats.
Researchers say that because the carbon dioxide released during combustion comes from renewable sources, the net CO2 emission over the fuel’s lifecycle also are reduced.
text:
Rotorcraft SAF Study Confirms Engines Burn Cleaner, Greener

by Tony Osborne (Aviation Week/The Weekly of Business Aviation) A study in Germany on the use of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) in helicopters, has confirmed considerable reductions in soot particles, confirming cleaner and greener operation of rotorcraft.

The trials performed by Germany’s DLR Aerospace Center and air rescue service ADAC using Airbus H145 and H135 twin-engine light helicopters found that the engines running on the SAF blend emitted significantly fewer ultrafine particles (UFP), and that both the Safran Arriel and Pratt and Whitney Canada engines were able to run “smoothly and reliably with the SAF blend.” The helicopters completed a combined 1,800 flight hr. using a blend of SAF and conventional aviation fuel.

According to the DLR, the fuel contained up to 38% SAF that was produced from recycled vegetable or animal fats. Researchers say that because the carbon dioxide released during combustion comes from renewable sources, the net CO2 emission over the fuel’s lifecycle also are reduced.

title: OMV Switches On Austria's Largest Green Hydrogen Plant To Power Cleaner Fuels
description:
OMV has officially fired up Austria’s largest green hydrogen plant, right at its Schwechat refinery just outside Vienna.
Using renewable electricity and PEM electrolysis tech, the facility is set to churn out up to 1,500 tons of green hydrogen per year.
That’s a big deal—not just for the refinery, but for the future of hydrogen production in Europe.
Thanks to its location in a major industrial area just outside Vienna, the new plant isn’t just reducing OMV’s emissions—it’s also being smart about logistics, fully integrating green hydrogen into daily refinery operations.
It’s a key piece in OMV’s broader plan to go from traditional fossil fuels to a cleaner, greener future.
text:
OMV has officially fired up Austria’s largest green hydrogen plant, right at its Schwechat refinery just outside Vienna. Using renewable electricity and PEM electrolysis tech, the facility is set to churn out up to 1,500 tons of green hydrogen per year. That’s a big deal—not just for the refinery, but for the future of hydrogen production in Europe.

The €25 million project isn’t just about producing fuel—it’s about cutting CO₂ emissions by up to 15,000 tons annually. On top of that, the clean hydrogen will be a game-changer for making renewable diesel (HVO) and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), helping give air and land transport a much-needed sustainable boost.

A Big Step Toward a Cleaner Energy Future

This isn’t just a shiny new piece of tech—it’s a clear sign that OMV is serious about walking the talk when it comes to sustainable energy. The move supports the EU’s climate objectives and keeps OMV in step with upcoming rules like Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) certification.

Thanks to its location in a major industrial area just outside Vienna, the new plant isn’t just reducing OMV’s emissions—it’s also being smart about logistics, fully integrating green hydrogen into daily refinery operations. It’s a key piece in OMV’s broader plan to go from traditional fossil fuels to a cleaner, greener future.

Hydrogen at the Heart of Industrial Decarbonization

title: Hy2gen Secures €47M To Expand Green Hydrogen And Ammonia Projects Across Europe ...
description:
Where the Magic Happens: Projects With Purpose Hy2gen isn’t just tossing darts at a map.
Germany (Werlte): Home to the Atlantis plant extension, this site officially kicked off renewable hydrogen production in 2023—already up and running.
Go Big or Go Home: Industrial Scale That Moves the Needle Hy2gen isn’t messing around when it comes to scale.
That’s why projects like Iverson in Norway (for clean ammonia) and Courant in Canada (for renewable ammonium nitrate) are a big deal.
The Bottom Line Hydrogen isn’t some climate cure-all—but it could be a critical link in the chain.
text:
Hy2gen Doubles Down on Renewable Hydrogen with Fresh €47M Boost

When it comes to cutting carbon from heavy industries and aviation, there’s no time to waste—and Hy2gen AG just got a serious shot in the arm to keep that momentum going.

The Germany-based company, which focuses on renewable hydrogen production and fuels like clean ammonia and e-fuels (also called RFNBOs), has secured a €47 million funding round to scale up its fast-growing portfolio. We’re talking projects already spread across Germany, France, Norway, and Canada, with plenty more on the way.

This isn’t just a cash influx—it’s fuel for what could be one of the most ambitious industrial decarbonization roadmaps out there, with more than 3.4 GW of planned electrolysis capacity and a staggering 15 GW in development around the world.

Meet the Big Players Backing the Hydrogen Push

Leading this latest round is Hy24, a powerhouse investment firm devoted to building a global low-carbon hydrogen economy. Hy24’s Clean H2 Infra Fund—one of the biggest in the sector—has some serious muscle behind it, with names like Air Liquide, TotalEnergies, and Plug Power on board.

Joining the party are strategic tech and impact investors like Technip Energies, BenDa, and Rely. So this isn’t just about money—it’s about teaming up with folks who know how to build big and move fast in energy infrastructure.

Where the Magic Happens: Projects With Purpose

Hy2gen isn’t just tossing darts at a map. Every project is rooted in natural advantages—whether that’s access to cheap renewables, world-class ports, or smart policy environments.

Germany (Werlte): Home to the Atlantis plant extension, this site officially kicked off renewable hydrogen production in 2023—already up and running.

France (Fos-Marseille): With a 390 MW electrolyzer coming online, this project aims to crank out 75,000 tons of e-SAF (electro-sustainable aviation fuel) per year, helping airlines stay ahead of tightening fuel regulations.

Norway (Iverson project): This one taps into hydropower to create 200,000 tons of clean ammonia annually—perfect for export in a decarbonizing world.

Canada (Courant project): Still in late-stage planning, this plant focuses on producing renewable ammonia and ammonium nitrate for agriculture and industrial uses where emissions are notoriously tough to wipe out.

The Moment Is Now: Hydrogen Goes from Hype to Reality

Let’s face it—for years, talk about sustainable energy and green hydrogen often felt like just that: talk. But the tide has turned.

Global demand is soaring for zero-carbon alternatives. Companies in aviation, fertilizer, and industry are scrambling to get ahead of climate targets. Governments from Brussels to Ottawa are backing the push with real funding and serious regulations.

And in that context, Hy2gen’s ability to take projects from concept to shovel-ready couldn’t be more perfectly timed. This round of funding isn’t about dreaming—it’s about building.

Tech That Delivers: From Power to Molecules

At the heart of Hy2gen’s model is good old-fashioned electrolysis—using clean electricity to split water into hydrogen and oxygen. But they’re not stopping there.

Hy2gen is betting big on Power-to-X technology, which converts renewable electricity into the high-demand fuels industries already use—like e-SAF or clean ammonia. By focusing on Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBOs), they’re aiming straight at the sectors most in need of cleaner alternatives—and the ones that traditional hydrogen developers often overlook.

Go Big or Go Home: Industrial Scale That Moves the Needle

Hy2gen isn’t messing around when it comes to scale. With 3.4 GW of electrolysis already in planning and construction—and another 15 GW lined up behind it—they’re setting a new bar.

If even part of that capacity goes live, it won’t just be a win for hydrogen production. It could reshape regional economies, shorten supply chains, smooth out fuel pricing, and finally give industrial sectors a reliable, clean fuel source they can bet on.

Taking on the Not-So-Glamorous, but Vital Sectors

Let’s be honest—fuel and fertilizer aren’t exactly headline-grabbers. But if we want to hit decarbonization goals, these sectors can’t be ignored.

That’s why projects like Iverson in Norway (for clean ammonia) and Courant in Canada (for renewable ammonium nitrate) are a big deal. They’re targeting hard-to-decarbonize areas most companies shy away from.

Meanwhile, back in France, Hy2gen’s aviation-focused e-SAF project lands at just the right moment, with regulators turning up the heat for cleaner jet fuels.

Don’t expect all this to go online tomorrow—but with construction on Courant expected to kick off by 2027 and funding now locked in, we’re a lot closer than we were yesterday.

The Bottom Line

Hydrogen isn’t some climate cure-all—but it could be a critical link in the chain. And if companies like Hy2gen keep turning ideas into action across borders and sectors, we might just see how real sustainable energy transformation kicks off.

The big question now? How fast can they bring those 3.4 GW online. Because whether it’s for planes, plants, or fertilizer—every gigawatt counts.

title: OMV Launches Austria's Largest Green Hydrogen Production Plant to Drive Sustainable ...
description:
(IN BRIEF) OMV has launched Austria’s largest green hydrogen production plant at its Schwechat refinery, with an annual capacity of up to 1,500 metric tons.
This EUR 25 million investment will significantly reduce CO2 emissions by up to 15,000 metric tons per year.
The green hydrogen produced will be used to make sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and renewable diesel (HVO).
The green hydrogen plant is certified under the Renewable Energy Directive (EU) 2018/2001 (RED II) for producing renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO).
EUR 25 million About making green hydrogen via PEM electrolysis Making green hydrogen through PEM electrolysis involves splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen using renewable electricity.
text:
(IN BRIEF) OMV has launched Austria’s largest green hydrogen production plant at its Schwechat refinery, with an annual capacity of up to 1,500 metric tons. This EUR 25 million investment will significantly reduce CO2 emissions by up to 15,000 metric tons per year. The green hydrogen produced will be used to make sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and renewable diesel (HVO). The plant, powered entirely by renewable electricity, is central to OMV’s commitment to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

(PRESS RELEASE) VIENNA, 1-May-2025 — /EuropaWire/ — OMV has successfully launched its green hydrogen production plant at the Schwechat refinery near Vienna, marking a significant step in the company’s efforts to support the transition to more sustainable fuels and chemicals. The plant, the largest of its kind in Austria, has an annual capacity to produce up to 1,500 metric tons of green hydrogen, powered entirely by renewable electricity from wind, hydro, and solar sources. This innovation is set to reduce CO2 emissions by up to 15,000 metric tons per year, equivalent to the annual CO2 consumption of 2,000 people.

The 10-megawatt green hydrogen facility, which represents a EUR 25 million investment, will play a critical role in producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and renewable diesel (HVO) at the Schwechat refinery. The plant uses a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolyzer to produce green hydrogen through electrolysis, a process that splits water into hydrogen and oxygen using renewable electricity.

Martijn van Koten, OMV Board Member for Fuels & Feedstock and Chemicals, commented, “With the start-up of Austria’s largest electrolysis plant, we are rethinking how everyday essentials are produced sustainably. Green hydrogen is at the core of this transformation, serving as a key enabler in producing sustainable fuels and chemicals, while advancing the decarbonization of our Schwechat site. This initiative not only helps advance Europe’s climate goals but also strengthens the resilience of local production and supply chains.”

OMV has committed to becoming net-zero by 2050, with a focus on pioneering projects in areas such as geothermal energy, sustainable aviation fuel, and chemical recycling. Green hydrogen, generated via electrolysis, is a central element of OMV’s transformation strategy, playing a vital role in the production processes at its refineries.

The green hydrogen plant is certified under the Renewable Energy Directive (EU) 2018/2001 (RED II) for producing renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO). The project has been supported by the Climate and Energy Fund Austria and is part of the WIVA P&G Hydrogen Initiative Model Region Austria Power & Gas. Kommunalkredit also provided crucial support during the development phase to ensure the project’s successful completion.

Key Facts about the Green Hydrogen Plant:

Location: OMV Schwechat refinery, 2320 Schwechat/Lower Austria

Capacity: 10 megawatts

Start of Operation: April 2025

Production Volume: Up to 1,500 metric tons of green hydrogen per year

CO2 Emission Savings: Up to 15,000 metric tons per year

Investment Volume: Approx. EUR 25 million

About making green hydrogen via PEM electrolysis

Making green hydrogen through PEM electrolysis involves splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen using renewable electricity. At the anode, oxygen and positively charged hydrogen protons are generated. These protons pass through the PEM, and at the cathode, they combine with electrons to form hydrogen gas. Since water consists of two hydrogen atoms for every oxygen atom, the process produces twice as much hydrogen as oxygen.

See also the OMV blog post for more details.

About OMV Aktiengesellschaft

It is our purpose to re-invent essentials for sustainable living. OMV is transitioning to become an integrated sustainable chemicals, fuels and energy company with a focus on circular economy solutions. By gradually switching over to the low carbon business, OMV is striving to achieve net zero by 2050 at the latest. In 2024, the company generated revenues of 34 billion euros with a diverse and talented workforce of around 23,600 employees worldwide. OMV shares are traded on the Vienna Stock Exchange (OMV) and in the US as American Depository Receipts (OMVKY). For more information, please visit www.omv.com.

International Media Relations

Brigitte Köck

Tel: +43 (1) 40440-0

title: Pittsburgh Airport To More Than Double On-Site Solar Field | Aviation Week Network
description:
Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT) will significantly expand its on-site solar field, adding 12 acres of panels to more than double the amount of energy produced.
PIT in 2021 completed a 3-megawatt solar array comprising nearly 10,000 panels.
The Pennsylvania airport unveiled plans on April 29 to add 11,216 solar panels to its array atop a closed landfill on airport property.
IMG Energy will own the expanded field and has committed to supply 100% of the energy generated by the new solar panels to Duquesne Light Co., the regional power provider.
PIT noted it has saved more than $1 million in annual electricity costs since the solar array became operational in 2021.
text:
Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT) will significantly expand its on-site solar field, adding 12 acres of panels to more than double the amount of energy produced.

PIT in 2021 completed a 3-megawatt solar array comprising nearly 10,000 panels. The microgrid fully powers airport facilities. PIT maintains a connection to the region’s main electric grid as a backup.

The Pennsylvania airport unveiled plans on April 29 to add 11,216 solar panels to its array atop a closed landfill on airport property. “This expansion of the existing 8-acre solar array with an additional 12 acres will enable the generation of an additional 4.7 megawatts of clean energy,” PIT said in a statement.

The project is expected to be completed in 2027.

The expansion will not be a part of the PIT microgrid providing the airport’s electricity, but will supply energy to the regional electric grid. “We are maximizing the use of airport assets for the betterment of the region,” PIT CEO Christina Cassotis said.

IMG Energy will own the expanded field and has committed to supply 100% of the energy generated by the new solar panels to Duquesne Light Co., the regional power provider.

PIT noted it has saved more than $1 million in annual electricity costs since the solar array became operational in 2021.

title: DfT official hails Labour's support for aviation sector - Travel Weekly
description:
Relations between the government and aviation industry are in “a materially different place” than a year ago, according to a senior Department for Transport (DfT) official.
Michael Stark, deputy director for aviation, insisted: “The government has been very clear about the importance of aviation to the UK economy.” He noted: “The chancellor has given firm backing to Heathrow, and the transport secretary has made clear there is no contradiction between pushing on growth and decarbonisation.
That means pushing on sustainable aviation fuel [SAF].
It also means accelerating airspace modernisation.” Stark suggested “times have changed” since a year ago, saying: “We’re in a materially different place.” Richard Mumford, a partner at specialist aviation law firm Clyde & Co, agreed, saying: “There is a lot more talk about the economic benefits of aviation.” He described the “general tone” of discussion around government policy and aviation a year ago as “defensive”.
text:
Relations between the government and aviation industry are in “a materially different place” than a year ago, according to a senior Department for Transport (DfT) official.

Michael Stark, deputy director for aviation, insisted: “The government has been very clear about the importance of aviation to the UK economy.”

He noted: “The chancellor has given firm backing to Heathrow, and the transport secretary has made clear there is no contradiction between pushing on growth and decarbonisation. That means pushing on sustainable aviation fuel [SAF]. It also means accelerating airspace modernisation.”

Stark suggested “times have changed” since a year ago, saying: “We’re in a materially different place.”

Richard Mumford, a partner at specialist aviation law firm Clyde & Co, agreed, saying: “There is a lot more talk about the economic benefits of aviation.” He described the “general tone” of discussion around government policy and aviation a year ago as “defensive”.

title: Flagship Government Jet Massively Reduces Sustainable Fuel Use Since Election
description:
Reeves justified her support for Heathrow’s expansion to environmentalists by claiming that Sustainable Aviation Fuel is “a game-changer in the way that we fly” – Labour has set demands for the aviation industry to use increasing proportions of SAF in all flights – 2% this year, 10% in 2030, and 22% in 2040.
The miracle fuel currently costs between two to seven times more than traditional jet fuel… Guido wanted to see if jet-loving Labour is walking the walk and instructed its FoI Unit to query the Cabinet Office on SAF’s use in the government’s flagship G-GBNI Airbus A321-253NX.
Keir’s favourite jet – and it’s a disappointing picture… Since the general election the Cabinet Office says G-GBNI has used the eco-fuel for only eight flights.
Seeing as publicly available flight data shows that particular Airbus has completed 111 flights since then that puts the proportion using SAF at a pitiful 7.2%.
To make it worse the Cabinet Office says “27% of all flights taken using the GBNI airframe” have used the fuel, which means there has been a massive decline since Labour came in.

title: Neste starts SAF production at Rotterdam refinery - Oils & Fats International
description:
The refinery had been modified to enable Neste to produce up to 500,000 tonnes/year of SAF bringing its global SAF production capability to 1.5M tonnes/year, the company said on 9 April.
“Our SAF production capability, now also in Rotterdam, enables us to significantly contribute to the implementation of the ReFuelEU Aviation Regulation and similar SAF mandates,” Neste CEO Heikki Malinen said.
This would make the refinery the world’s largest facility producing renewable diesel and SAF, the company said.
Scheduled for completion in 2027, the expansion would increase Neste’s total global renewable fuels production capacity to 6.8M tonnes/year, including SAF output of 2.2M tonnes.
In addition to the Rotterdam refinery, Neste has SAF production facilities at its refineries in Singapore and Porvoo, Finland.
text:
The refinery had been modified to enable Neste to produce up to 500,000 tonnes/year of SAF bringing its global SAF production capability to 1.5M tonnes/year, the company said on 9 April.

“Our SAF production capability, now also in Rotterdam, enables us to significantly contribute to the implementation of the ReFuelEU Aviation Regulation and similar SAF mandates,” Neste CEO Heikki Malinen said.

“Policies like these are crucial to ramping-up SAF production and usage … At the same time, it requires support and close cooperation across the whole aviation ecosystem to accelerate the energy transition and related emission reductions.”

In addition to the recent modifications to the refinery, Neste said it was continuing its strategic growth investment project in Rotterdam which would more than double the company’s production capacity at its refinery there to 2.7M tonnes/year of renewable products.

This would make the refinery the world’s largest facility producing renewable diesel and SAF, the company said.

Scheduled for completion in 2027, the expansion would increase Neste’s total global renewable fuels production capacity to 6.8M tonnes/year, including SAF output of 2.2M tonnes.

In addition to the Rotterdam refinery, Neste has SAF production facilities at its refineries in Singapore and Porvoo, Finland.

title: OMV Launches Austria's Largest Green Hydrogen Facility - ChemAnalyst
description:
OMV has officially launched operations at its new green hydrogen production facility in Schwechat, near Vienna.
The company invested approximately 25 million euros into the site, which can produce up to 1,500 metric tons of green hydrogen annually.
“Green hydrogen is central to this transition, enabling lower-emission production at our Schwechat site.
Green hydrogen, produced via electrolysis, will play a central role in powering OMV’s refining operations and reducing overall emissions.
Green hydrogen is produced through PEM (polymer electrolyte membrane) electrolysis, a process that splits water into hydrogen and oxygen using electricity generated from renewable sources.
text:
OMV has officially launched operations at its new green hydrogen production facility in Schwechat, near Vienna. With a capacity of 10 megawatts, the plant is now the largest of its kind in Austria. The company invested approximately 25 million euros into the site, which can produce up to 1,500 metric tons of green hydrogen annually.

This green hydrogen will serve a pivotal role in manufacturing more sustainable fuels and chemicals, including sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and hydrogenated vegetable oil (HVO), also known as renewable diesel. The hydrogen is produced using a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolyzer, powered entirely by renewable energy sources such as wind, hydro, and solar.

The facility is expected to cut up to 15,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions each year—comparable to the annual emissions of about 2,000 people. This milestone supports OMV’s broader strategy to reduce its carbon footprint and advance energy transformation.

“With the launch of Austria’s largest electrolysis plant, we are redefining how essential fuels and chemicals are produced,” said Martijn van Koten, OMV executive board member for fuels, feedstock, and chemicals. “Green hydrogen is central to this transition, enabling lower-emission production at our Schwechat site. Developing local hydrogen production and supply chains also strengthens Europe’s industrial and climate resilience.”

The plant has been certified under the European Union’s Renewable Energy Directive (RED II) for producing renewable fuels of non-biological origin (RFNBOs). It is part of Austria’s WIVA P&G—Hydrogen Initiative Model Region Power & Gas—and received backing from the Climate and Energy Fund Austria. Financial support during the development phase was also provided by Kommunalkredit.

This project is one of OMV’s key transformation efforts as the company works toward achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. Additional initiatives include investing in geothermal energy, chemical recycling, and expanding sustainable aviation fuel capabilities. Green hydrogen, produced via electrolysis, will play a central role in powering OMV’s refining operations and reducing overall emissions.

The expertise gained through this facility is expected to serve as a model for future green hydrogen projects and help OMV build a more sustainable and secure energy future.

Green hydrogen is produced through PEM (polymer electrolyte membrane) electrolysis, a process that splits water into hydrogen and oxygen using electricity generated from renewable sources. At the anode, water molecules are broken down into oxygen and positively charged hydrogen ions (protons). These protons pass through the PEM to the cathode, where they combine with electrons to form hydrogen gas. Because water contains two hydrogen atoms for every oxygen atom, the process yields twice as much hydrogen as oxygen.

title: Boozman, Thompson, Klobuchar talk farm policy, SNAP cut in reconciliation
authors: Jerry Hagstrom, The Hagstrom Report, Jerry Hagstrom, The Hagstrom Report
description:
Boozman, Thompson and Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., ranking member on the Senate Agriculture Committee, spoke in separate sessions to the North American Agricultural Journalists.
Boozman noted that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program contains a provision to account for inflation but farm programs do not.
Boozman maintained that addressing basic farm programs and SNAP in the reconciliation bill will make it easier to pass a farm bill that deals with other programs, but some Democrats have said the opposite.
Republicans need to “be careful” about raising reference prices that trigger farm subsidies in reconciliation, Klobuchar said.
If the Senate goes “too deep” into SNAP cuts, it will be hard to pass a farm bill, she said.
text:
Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman John Boozman, R-Ark., and House Agriculture Committee Chairman Glenn Thompson, R-Pa., said Tuesday they are determined to include more money for basic farm subsidies and crop insurance in the reconciliation bill but are not yet certain how to handle a cut to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.

Boozman, Thompson and Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., ranking member on the Senate Agriculture Committee, spoke in separate sessions to the North American Agricultural Journalists. Rep. Angie Craig, D-Minn., ranking member on House Agriculture, canceled a scheduled appearance because she was announcing her candidacy for the senate to succeed retiring Sen. Tina Smith, D-Minn.

Boozman said he hopes the reconciliation bill can update “risk management” programs for farmers, which he later confirmed means the reference prices that trigger the agriculture risk coverage (ARC) and price loss coverage (PLC) programs and crop insurance.

“Right now, unless you are in the cattle business, it is going to cost you more to grow that crop than what you are going to receive,” Boozman said. Bankers, he noted, told Congress that they could not finance farmers this year if farmers did not get the $10 billion that was in the funding bill that passed at the end of 2024.

Boozman noted that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program contains a provision to account for inflation but farm programs do not. Boozman maintained that addressing basic farm programs and SNAP in the reconciliation bill will make it easier to pass a farm bill that deals with other programs, but some Democrats have said the opposite.

Boozman said he agrees with Health and Human Services Secretary Robert Kennedy Jr. that diets need to improve to avoid diabetes but he also said that Kennedy, who last week said sugar is “poison,” needs to “be careful about going too far. Some of the things he is talking about don’t fall within his jurisdiction.”

Boozman added that saying sugar “is poison is pretty extreme” and that statements about food need to be based on “sound science and common sense.”

On Arkansas Republican Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders’ plan to ask the Agriculture Department for a waiver to stop SNAP participants from buying sweetened beverages with their benefits, Boozman said that issue has come up before in farm bill debates but now “has a lot more momentum.” There are “concerns” about how a waiver would be administered, he said.

Boozman said there will be no cuts to current SNAP benefit levels in the reconciliation bill.

The Senate reconciliation bill instructions call for only a $1 billion cut to programs under the Senate Agriculture Committee’s jurisdiction, but the House instructions are for $230 billion.

Thompson said he also favors including increases for ARC, PLC and crop insurance in the reconciliation bill and that he would be “more comfortable” with a lower cut than $230 billion, which is expected to come at least mostly from SNAP.

Thompson also said he is not “looking to cut benefits” in the SNAP program, but he appeared more open to proposals to require the states to pay part of the SNAP benefit. Thompson noted that “states are now trying to define and tweak SNAP when they don’t pay for them.”

Thompson said he believes the House Agriculture Committee will mark up its portion of the reconciliation bill next week.

Thompson pointed out that he wants to make SNAP benefits available to former prisoners and to eliminate the so-called “poverty cliff” that means people who get a small increase in pay can lose their “safety net.”

Thompson called Kennedy’s statement that sugar is poison “a personal opinion.” When a reporter pointed out that Kennedy is the nation’s top health official, Thompson said, “So what?” He added he would “love to have a day with him to explain how healthy our commodities are.”

Thompson praised the Trump administration and Agriculture Secretary Brook Rollins in particular for being open to feedback.

Klobuchar said she is “very disturbed” by the actions the Trump administration is taking on the rural economy. With tariffs, Klobuchar said, “small farmers are roadkill.”

Klobuchar said her Republican colleagues are also worried, but the question is whether they will “stand up and vote” against Trump policies.

There is a lot of support for sustainable aviation fuel, now called synthetic aviation fuel, which could be given certainty through the 45Z guidance process, Klobuchar said.

Republicans need to “be careful” about raising reference prices that trigger farm subsidies in reconciliation, Klobuchar said.

If the Senate goes “too deep” into SNAP cuts, it will be hard to pass a farm bill, she said.

title: ATOBA, easyJet and World Fuel sign MoU to develop SAF supply - ADS Advance
description:
ATOBA uniquely facilitates the development of SAF production through its upstream and downstream SAF offtake portfolio management.
World Fuel intends to manage logistics, blending, storage and regulatory fulfillment for the EU and UK mandates.
World Fuel’s role in ensuring the seamless integration of SAF into easyJet’s supply chain underscores the parties’ joint commitment to developing an efficient and compliant end-to-end sustainable aviation fuel supply chain.
Raminder Shergill, Director of Fuel Strategy at easyJet commented: “We are deeply committed to fostering the growth of the Sustainable Aviation Fuel industry and are thrilled to see ATOBA introduce their innovative approach to catalysing the development of the SAF market.
By managing logistics and regulatory compliance, we work to ensure the seamless integration of sustainable aviation fuel in the market, empower producers and connect sustainability-focused customers with innovative supply.”
text:
Image courtesy easyJet

The agreement supports the airline’s decarbonisation strategy and is expected to unlock the SAF value chain through the combination of ATOBA’s SAF aggregation, enabling management of pricing and supply volatility risk for airlines and will be further enhanced by World Fuel’s global jet fuel logistics, blending, storage and distribution infrastructure.

The agreement is an important step toward scaling advanced SAF technologies and is intended to support easyJet's decarbonisation journey.

The SAF market is facing challenges in expanding at the rate demanded by environmental needs and regulatory mandates. While producers need long-term, stable pricing contracts to ensure a return on their investments, easyJet is seeking competitive SAF market prices in the context of a nascent industry with diverse competing technologies. This conflict of expectations currently hinders the development of SAF production projects and ATOBA’s unique business model brings a compelling solution.

ATOBA uniquely facilitates the development of SAF production through its upstream and downstream SAF offtake portfolio management. By offtaking from diversified producers that use production technologies like Alcohol to Jet, Gas-Fischer Tropsch, or Power to Liquids, ATOBA mitigates technological and pricing risks associated with the various SAF production pathways and facilitates the closing of long-term offtake agreements among airlines, jet-fuel distributors, SAF producers and financial institutions, which are essential for scaling the industry.

World Fuel intends to manage logistics, blending, storage and regulatory fulfillment for the EU and UK mandates. World Fuel’s role in ensuring the seamless integration of SAF into easyJet’s supply chain underscores the parties’ joint commitment to developing an efficient and compliant end-to-end sustainable aviation fuel supply chain.

Raminder Shergill, Director of Fuel Strategy at easyJet commented: “We are deeply committed to fostering the growth of the Sustainable Aviation Fuel industry and are thrilled to see ATOBA introduce their innovative approach to catalysing the development of the SAF market.

“By addressing the long-term offtake challenges that have hindered investment in SAF projects, ATOBA’s approach paves the way for accelerated industry expansion, greater investment confidence, and credible pricing and supply security for easyJet.”

Arnaud Namer, co-founder and CEO of ATOBA Energy, added: “We are proud to partner with easyJet and World Fuel, two aviation industry leaders taking bold and proactive steps to accelerate aviation’s transition to Sustainable Aviation Fuels. With their expertise in highly efficient operational cost management, they are setting a strong precedent for the industry. We are excited to support their transition through our SAF aggregation services, providing airlines with long-term competitive advantages as they shift toward more sustainable fuels.”

World Fuel’s Senior Vice President (EMEA), Duncan Storey, said: “Our collaboration with easyJet and ATOBA, underscores our commitment to expanding global access to sustainable aviation fuel. By managing logistics and regulatory compliance, we work to ensure the seamless integration of sustainable aviation fuel in the market, empower producers and connect sustainability-focused customers with innovative supply.”

title: JAL operates 1st flight out of Kansai using domestic SAF under Fry to Fly scheme
description:
Japan Airlines has operated a flight out of Kansai International Airport (KIX) to Shanghai Pudong International Airport (PVG) using domestically mass-produced Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).
Flight JL891 departed Kansai at 10:13 local time on May 1, 2025, and after a flight time of two hours and 48 minutes, the Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner arrived in Shanghai at 12:01 noon local time.
The SAF, produced domestically from waste cooking oil collected all over Japan, was mass-produced at Saffaire Sky Energy’s manufacturing facility located in Osaka.
This is not the first time that JAL has used SAF from cooking oil on flights, but the Kansai to Shanghai flight marked the start of the implementation of a supply chain that enables continuous production and supply of SAF in Japan.
The flight, along with the production of SAF, is part of Japan Airlines’ Fly to Fry project, an initiative that aims to operate and fly all aircraft using SAF made from domestic resources, specifically waste cooking oil generated by households and businesses.

title: easyJet signs MoU for long-term SAF supply - Aerospace Global News
description:
easyJet, in partnership with World Fuel Services and ATOBA Energy, has agreed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for the development of a long-term supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for the low-cost carrier’s operations in Europe and the UK.
Through its upstream and downstream SAF offtake portfolio management, ATOBA can facilitate the scaling of SAF production, solving the financial dilemma between airlines and producers.
It offtakes from diversified producers using production technologies, such as Alcohol-to-Jet, Gas-Fsicher Tropsch, or Power-to-Liquids, thereby mitigating technological and pricing risks and supporting the closing of long-term offtake agreements between airlines, SAF producers and financial institutions.
“By addressing the long-term offtake challenges that have hindered investment in SAF projects, ATOBA’s approach paves the way for accelerated industry expansion, greater investment confidence and credible pricing and supply security,” he said.
At the end of 2024, easyJet signed a similar MoU also with World Fuel Services and Braathens Renavia in partnership with Mana Group, for the long-term supply of SAF.
text:
easyJet, in partnership with World Fuel Services and ATOBA Energy, has agreed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for the development of a long-term supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for the low-cost carrier’s operations in Europe and the UK.

With the SAF industry facing challenges in terms of scaling supply at the rate demanded by environmental needs and regulatory mandates, this agreement, which differs from previous MoUs as it will make use of ATOBA’s offtake agreements from diversified SAF producers and technologies, marks an important step in addressing the long-term offtake challenges that have hindered investment in SAF projects. Through the combination of ATOBA’s SAF aggregation, which will enable management of pricing and supply volatility risk for airlines, and World Fuel’s global jet fuel logisitics, blending, storage and distribution infrastructure, the agreement is expected to unlock the SAF value chain.

Through its upstream and downstream SAF offtake portfolio management, ATOBA can facilitate the scaling of SAF production, solving the financial dilemma between airlines and producers. It offtakes from diversified producers using production technologies, such as Alcohol-to-Jet, Gas-Fsicher Tropsch, or Power-to-Liquids, thereby mitigating technological and pricing risks and supporting the closing of long-term offtake agreements between airlines, SAF producers and financial institutions.

Raminder Shergill, director of tax & fuel strategy at easyJet explained that the low-cost carrier is seeking competitive SAF markets in the context of a nascent industry with diverse competing technologies. “By addressing the long-term offtake challenges that have hindered investment in SAF projects, ATOBA’s approach paves the way for accelerated industry expansion, greater investment confidence and credible pricing and supply security,” he said.

At the end of 2024, easyJet signed a similar MoU also with World Fuel Services and Braathens Renavia in partnership with Mana Group, for the long-term supply of SAF. It was announced at the time that this agreement is expected to provide the LCC with access to up to 150,000 tonnes of SAF (including up to 75,000 tonnes of eSAF) from 2030.
